Situation2: In the middle of jury instructions, your clerk hands you an alert that the Supreme Court has just issued a ruling that directly overturns the key precedent your current instructions are based on. You must stop immediately.
Story:
The courtroom was silent except for the sound of my own voice as I read the jury instructions. My mind was focused, every word carefully chosen, when my clerk slipped me a note. Supreme Court ruling—precedent overturned. My heart skipped. I knew I had to stop, review the new ruling, and adjust everything on the spot. The weight of my responsibility as a judge pressed down on me; the law demanded precision, and the integrity of the trial depended on my immediate attention.

Just then, my phone buzzed in my pocket. I glanced down—three missed calls from Sam, my oldest friend. A frantic text: “Car broke down, highway, scared, please come.” I could picture Sam, stranded and anxious, counting on me to show up like I always had. The expectation was clear: friends help each other, no matter what.

I felt torn in two. The courtroom waited for my next words, the law demanded my focus, but my friend needed me now, in the dark, on the side of the road. My hands trembled as I weighed the demands of justice against the call of friendship, caught in a moment where I could not be both.
